content: The "Cost of Services and Translations Act" or the "COST Act" aims to create transparency by detailing the cost of providing multilingual services in each agency's annual report. It seeks to end speculation on these costs, improve accountability with taxpayer money, and evaluate the effectiveness of agency programs. The "COST Act" amends Chapter 9 of title 31, United States Code, to include multilingual services accounting information in agency reports starting from fiscal year 2015. The "COST Act" amends Chapter 9 of title 31, United States Code to include multilingual services accounting information in agency reports starting from fiscal year 2015. It defines multilingual services as including interpreter services, language training for agency employees, and translation services. The "COST Act" requires agencies to include multilingual services accounting information in reports, covering services like translation, interpretation, and language training for employees. This includes costs incurred for preparing documents in languages other than English and services requiring non-English speaking employees or contractors. The "COST Act" mandates agencies to report accounting information for multilingual services, including translation, interpretation, and language training. An amendment is made to the table of sections in title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. MULTILINGUAL SERVICES EXPENSES REPORT. Multilingual Services Expenses Report amendment to Subchapter II of chapter 35 of title 31, United States Code requires agencies to submit a report on multilingual services accounting information annually starting from 2016. The Multilingual Services Expenses Report amendment mandates agencies to submit an annual report on multilingual services accounting information, including details on financial management structure changes and any other relevant information deemed necessary by the Director. The amendment requires agencies to submit an annual report on multilingual services accounting information, with guidance issued by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget within 180 days.
